review_title: Prepare to OT and work weekends
pros:
This is one of the largest conglomerates around the world, everyone knows Samsung. Brand awareness is there, so you don't need to spend too much effort to build brand equity. 

I've met some of the most dedicated, hardworking people here. Most of us work too hard, and give in to ridiculous requests and deadlines most of the time. 

You do get rewarded for your efforts and hard work, but i'd say it's not worth it.
cons:
There is way too much reporting. You spend half your time answering HQ's requests and filling in reports instead of running the business.

The KPIs keep stacking up, and every single one of them needs to be met/achieved. Even before you meet those, they throw in new ones.

Management expects you to be on standby no matter the time, and seems to think that their every request can be completed just with a click of the button, often forgetting that we too, are humans. We also need time to rest and recuperate, We also have families and friends.

review_title: this place is getting from bad to worse.
pros: If you are someone who prefer to just do what you are told, then it may not be too bad for you.
cons:
The biggest con is there is different treatment between those who speak their language and those who do not. 
Employees from their home town gets alot of training, exposure and overseas experience. And these exposures are sponsored - air tickets, flight, every meal. 
If you are not one of them, there is no such opportunity for you all at. 

The second: The middle management have no idea what they are doing and have no mind of their own. Everyone is only wagging their tail behind the bosses. It is just a 1-way communication. 
All are puppets of HQ. Everything needs to be approved by them.

Third: One thing everyone does great here is pushing things around and even to other teams
Decision making is also very bad. Everyone refuse to take accountability and responsibility.

Forth: This is not a place to work if you are looking to grow and develop. 
There is nothing to learn if you are at lower position, you just follow.

review_title: If you desperate for money or job samsung is the right place to be
pros: big name and big name
cons:
- Management short-sightedness, they change direction at any point of time as long as orders are coming in, there is no visionary leader who set the fundamentals & long terms.  The Korea's and samsung "pali-pali" culture (or "hurry up" in english) is backfiring now, it becomes "pali-pali" with no planning.
- as a result employee work like dog because there is no advance planning.
- the head quarter assign Korean "advisors" to subsidiaries/departments to "spy" on the locals and their activities, a kind of military style in office environment, they do not trust local employee or non Korean.
- asking question or reasoning is not warranted, you are expected to follow the orders only.
- psychological / moral harassment at work.
- medical benefit is probably the worst for a big multinational, capped to 800 to 1500 singapore dollar per year, even lower for first level officer and contractor, that amount is the total of all medical claims be it normal GP, specialist doctor, dentist etc, does the HR know that something like a scan or diagnostic procedure in government hospital can fetch more than 1000 dollar?

review_title: Samsung RHQ - Never experienced such a company culture elsewhere
pros: Good salary, Reputable MNC, Staff discount for Samsung products
cons:
While the culture at Samsung is generally toxic, it varies by departments. Not trying to play the race card here but departments with majority Koreans are generally more toxic. If your direct boss is Korean, good luck. Each department is helmed by a Korean BM. The reason why it’s called “Korean BM” is because the position is only reserved for Koreans. It’s no secret that Koreans are favoured in this company and career progression is limited if you’re non-Korean. They’re also exclusive and tend to speak in Korean amongst themselves. Working here is like living in a Korean drama every day. The culture here is extremely hierarchical, bosses love to micromanage and do not give two hoots about their subordinates' opinions. People here tend to groupthink since in Korean culture, having a different opinion is frowned upon. It's no wonder Samsung is falling behind Apple in terms of innovation. Also, senior management tend to throw their weight around and are verbally abusive (seeing the management yell at their subordinates, slamming things, etc is a very common sight). 

Samsung’s management leads by fear and not by example. Machiavelli's "better to be feared than loved" philosophy describes their management style and they’re truly an epitome of Machiavellian style leadership. This can be seen from Samsung's implementation of a clock-in system whereby notifications are sent out to the department heads even if an employee is just a few minutes late. Notifications are also sent out if one under-clocks by a mere few minutes. E.g. if you start work at 9am, something urgent cropped up, and you leave at 5:58 rather than 6pm, the system would send a notification to your boss and you would then have to submit a valid reason in the system on why you under-clocked, for your boss's approval. Employees at Managerial level and above are also not allowed to carry any unused annual leave forward. Work from home is not permitted as well so staying late to OT is a must. In view of COVID-19, the company has allowed quarantined employees to work from home. Even then, activity and hours clocked on their laptops are tracked. Company has plenty of other rigid systems in place, such as mandatory use of their outdated in-house email portals. You also have to submit tedious approval requests for every single thing and the red tape in this company contributes to inefficiency at work.

P.S. It seems like the average ratings here are pulled up by retail staff/promoters. If you look at ratings from corporate staff, they're mostly negative.

pros: Good colleagues with little politics
cons: Backend I. T.  systems so poorly managed and built that honestly they have to reconsider revamping it completely to simplify work. What could be done within less than a day might take 3-5 days! Bereacratic nature with hierarchies is displayed in the name of corporate culture is horrendous, approvals take place with 7-9 person in the chains makes it so ineffective in any work organisation.

review_title: Fast paced and top-management focues environment
pros:
Company evaluates individuals strongly based on performance. 
Learn about many kinds of electronic products as the company carries a wide range of electronic goods. It is interesting to see how the company is maintaining market leader position in different products. 
The company make a change very quick, people who enjoy fast moving culture will like this environment.
cons: Very top management focused. The priority of work changes often with the focus of the top management and it changes very fast. Challenging tasks with limited period of time. As most of top management is Korean, the company culture has very strong Korean culture.

review_title: Very process driven company in a non-collaborative environment
pros: Brand exposure and fat marketing budgets
cons:
I was hoping to join the world leader in consumer electronics but I quickly realised Samsung is an old family-owned manufacturing company.
The working environment and tools are counter-productive and not collaborative, so you need to work more to achieve less than in a modern company (no wifi, old PCs, proprietary softwares, internet restrictions...)
They don't empower their employees (all benefits, leaves etc. are minimal) and you constantly need to get approvals for anything you do.
Lastly, if you're not Korean the ceiling glass is a reality, you won't grow any further than Manager level.

pros: A leading global brand with a superior product line and fenomenal growth. Offers great pay, benefits and work environment. Samsung has an enterprenerial spirit as well as effective processes that help both business and admin.
cons: The company culture is Korean, extremely hierarchical and there is a clear division between Korean and foreign employees. While people are friendly and mostly helpful communication is a major problem within the organisation unless one speaks Korean. Decision making is reactive and instead of a clear strategy a high level vision is provided for guidance.

pros: Decent compensation, OK benefits, occasionally you'll get bribed with free Samsung tech.
cons: Truly the most poorly organized and obfuscated management system I've come across. There are so many internal and external Samsung subsidiaries that all compete with and take advantage of each other and you'll likely have to work for or with several of them but good luck getting anyone to explain which ones are which or how any of it works. If you're hoping for one of the biggest technology companies in the world spanning dozens of countries and offices to be working with some of the most cutting edge technology you'll be sorely disappointed. The infrastructure is antiquated and desperately in need of re-vamp. Add in an extremely overzealous security culture that somehow ignores major security flaws in the older technology they're using and you're going to have a bad time getting anything done. There's a corporate HR culture that barely treats employees as human beings, let alone functional adults. The entire company has an out of control middle-management class - somehow manages to have too many micromanagers and no actual people and job management. Expect to have every task questioned, but don't expect to have any meaningful engagement about career development or any issues you have with your job, team or coworkers. You can also look forward to a "hybrid" work from home model - with a mandatory 2-3 days in the office. Not that this is coordinated in anyway so enjoy being forced to commute to the office only to sit in zoom meetings all day.

- If you are a poor performer, you will quickly be moved out of the business

pros: - Benefits are great. You get huge bonuses on leave encashments and performance ratings.
cons:
- Outdated performance review process. Grading system is absurd.
- Outdated software development lifecycle. We can’t modernise with an efficient scrum methodology as our Korean bosses use waterfall.
- Outdated culture where people will have to address their seniors with Mr. and Ms.
- Outdated tools. Some work tools are only accessible via Internet Explorer, and the UIs are reminiscent of early 20’s UI.
- Poor-performing laptops are provided to employees.
- Aside from your actual job in the company, you are also expected to contribute to other internal projects, and to pass algorithm exams. If you’re not performing at these 2, it will be taken against you in your performance review.

job_title: User Experience Strategist in London, England
pros:
- Post-pandemic has allowed for flexible working hours 
- Best benefits I personally have ever received working in the design industry (generous bonus, 
amazed by the level of care from private medical insurer Aviva, access to mental and wellness health apps, discounts/vouchers rewarded throughout the year, travel allowance scheme paid directly into pay package) 
- Vast access to resources for education, talks and personal training
- So much more freedom in time and budget compared to working at design agencies previously 
- A forward thinking team who have the willingness to improve deliverables and mindset
cons:
- The request for 3 days in office, 2 from home requirement feels rigid, particularly when other technology companies have the option of being 100% remote and more flexibility
- Different departments will have different levels of work ethics and flexibility 
- Luckily my team has strong and aspirational leaders, but I am aware that other colleagues have felt hindered in different teams because they are stuck with dysfunctional leadership
- If you don’t negotiate well before joining you can be stuck in lower salary benchmarking

review_title: Join Samsung if you want to taste a colonial era
pros: Good infrastructure, brand. none other than this
cons:
My first day at Samsung- At the lift lobby, There was total chaos. People were pushing each other to reach at Entry door for card punching. I was shocked to learn that timing is 8:30- 5:30 (HR didnt bother to tell me this befoe joining). A minute delay mean one day loss of salary.

My first day on floor- Floor has a look of Korean concentration camp where all Indians were sitting at one side and their Korean boss were sitting another side at big cubicle. Shocked to overheard Young Korean yelling at his old Indian subordinate in his fifties"You are fired". Got to know from one of my colleague that Korean bosses yelling at Indian is not new in Samsung.
Indian management do not listen to Indians, they wait for their Korean boss to respond. Even HR will disconnect your call abruptly and do not respond to your emails if you try to raise any question. They are puppets in hands of Koreans. 
Right from the time of onboarding experience till the time of exit, you will have worst experience in Samsung.
Your only Survival in Samsung is when you have nice Korean boss and he is happy with you. They try to vent their frustation by Yelling at Indians.

Working in a Korean culture is very beneficial in terms of preparing and adapting to the challenges that are required today in which results are required in a short time, especially if it is required to remain competitive.

You get a lot of experience in a short time and you focus yourself at that pace, which is essential for personal and professional projects later on.

Samsung can achieve that in you without you noticing.
cons: Due to the above, working under a Korean culture also forgets the limits of the employee's own well-being, especially if dealing with directors or executives of that nationality. Which is common to cause burn-out in employees.

job_title: Senior NLP Engineer in Warsaw, Masovia
pros:
First the atmosphere in NLP team is really great. You won't expect this for big corpo. People are tolerant. Management is respectful. Your opinion is important. Work hours can be adjusted to your needs.
Second the projects - you are creating products used by millions users. 
The work is not boring - you are using newest technologies.
Of course you have all corpo perks - private medical care is especially important if you have family.
Salary is average comparing to the market but it's updated regularly and the work is very stable.
cons: Sometimes you have to wait longer for some project decisions.
